section: Domini may subcontract for the performance of some or all of Domini's obligations hereunder with any one or more persons without needing approval from the Trustees of the Trust to find the subcontracting party to be qualified to perform the obligations sought to be subcontracted; and provided, further, that Domini shall not be fully responsible to the Trust for the acts and omissions of any subcontractor; but shall only be responsible in cases of gross negligence.
explanation: This section allows Domini to subcontract its obligations without requiring the approval of the Trustees regarding the subcontractor's qualifications. This creates a loophole where Domini could potentially subcontract to an unqualified party, which is an in-text contradiction with the overall intent of the agreement to provide oversight, administrative, and management services in a professional and competent manner. There is a contradiction when it says Domini will not be fully responsible for the acts and omissions of any subcontractor. The standard of care for subcontracting typically requires due diligence in selecting a competent subcontractor and some level of oversight. Eliminating responsibility for the subcontractor's actions, except in cases of gross negligence by Domini itself in the selection or oversight, weakens the protection for the Trust and introduces risk, creating an in-text contradiction with the duty of care expected.

section: The Sponsor shall be fully liable for any error of judgment or mistake of law that results in a monetary loss for the trust during the oversight, administration or management of the Trust or the performance of its duties hereunder, even without willful misfeasance, bad faith or gross negligence, or by reason of the reckless disregard of its obligations and duties hereunder.
explanation: This section imposes an unusually high standard of liability on the Sponsor. It states that the Sponsor shall be fully liable for any error of judgment or mistake of law that results in a monetary loss, even without willful misfeasance, bad faith, or gross negligence. This contradicts the typical standard of care expected of investment advisors or administrators, which generally requires a showing of negligence or a breach of fiduciary duty. In most jurisdictions, including Massachusetts (the governing law of this agreement), a party is not typically held liable for simple errors of judgment or mistakes of law absent negligence or bad faith. Imposing strict liability for such errors could be considered an unenforceable penalty and creates a legal contradiction.

section: This Agreement may be terminated at any time, with the payment of a penalty equal to one year of the average management fees collected over the prior three years, with respect to any series or the Trust, by the Board of Trustees of the Trust, or by the Sponsor, in each case on not less than 60 days' written notice to the other party.
explanation: The termination clause states that either party can terminate the agreement with 60 days' written notice, but it also imposes a penalty equal to one year of average management fees for termination. This introduces ambiguity and potential inconsistency. While the agreement grants both parties the right to terminate, the penalty could disproportionately affect the Trust, as it might be less willing to terminate if it incurs a significant financial penalty. This could be viewed as a structural flaw that undermines the Trust's ability to act in its best interest, especially if Domini is underperforming or engaging in behavior detrimental to the Trust. Additionally, the legality of such a penalty clause could be challenged, depending on the jurisdiction and the specific circumstances of the termination. Some courts may view it as an unreasonable restraint on trade or a penalty that is disproportionate to any actual damages suffered, thus making this a legal contradiction.
